title: 7 Effective Ways to Reset Your Keyboard

steps.title: Press and hold the specified keyboard key.
steps.content: Press and hold the specified keyboard key. Many newer keyboards have a key dedicated to resetting your keyboard back to factory settings, which can be useful if you created some macros or personalizations with your keyboard that you no longer use or want. For example, to reset a wireless Corsair keyboard, turn it off, press and hold the ESC key, and turn the keyboard back on. The keyboard lights will flash if the reset is successful. If you have a K95 RGB Platinum or any MK2 keyboard from Corsair, unplug it from your computer, press and hold the ESC key, and plug it back in. It'll flash, then you can unplug it and plug it back in again. However, if you have an K55 keyboard from Corsair, unplug the keyboard and press FN + F4 . Plug the keyboard back into your computer while holding these keys, then open the iCUE software and update the keyboard's firmware. [1] X Research source Alternatively, for an ASUS Claymore II keyboard, press and hold FN + F3 while plugged into the computer, and the lights should be red, flashing or strobing to indicate that you've reset the keyboard. Note that you should look up your specific keyboard for the reset procedure since every manufacturer has different instructions.

steps.title: Use the associated software to reset your keyboard.
steps.content: Use the associated software to reset your keyboard. Some keyboards come with software that you can use to easily and quickly revert your keyboard back to factory settings. For example, all Logitech keyboards that have access to Logi Options+ can find the option to reset to factory settings in Settings .

steps.title: Switch the keyboard language using the Input menu icon.
steps.content: Switch the keyboard language using the Input menu icon. If you're seeing characters from the wrong language as you type, it's usually because the wrong language is selected as the input language. To switch to a different language quickly, click the current language in the taskbar, just left of the system clock. It's usually at the bottom-right corner of the screen. Then, select the language you want to type in. If you don't see the Input menu icon, don't see the language you need, or want to change your default keyboard input language, continue to the next step.

steps.title: Open Settings .
steps.content: Open Settings . To do so, click the Start menu and select the gear icon at the bottom-left corner.

steps.title: Click Time & language.
steps.content: Click Time & language . It's a clock-shaped icon in the middle of the window.

steps.title: Click the Language tab.
steps.content: Click the Language tab. It's in the left panel. If you only have one language installed under "Preferred languages," you won't see the Input menu in the system tray. This icon only shows up if multiple languages or inputs are installed.

steps.title: Click the Keyboard icon.
steps.content: Click the Keyboard icon. It's in the upper portion of the right panel.

steps.title: Select Use language list (recommended) from the menu.
steps.content: Select Use language list (recommended) from the menu. It's at the top of the window. This tells Windows to use the first language in your list as the default language. Click the back button to return to your Language settings.

steps.title: Move your preferred language to the top of the list.
steps.content: Move your preferred language to the top of the list. To do this, select the language and click the up-arrow until it's at the top of the list. Windows will now default to using the language at the top of the list if you have multiple languages installed. If you don't see the language you want to use, click the + next to "Add a language," select the language, click Next , and then click Install language pack to install it. You can remove a language you no longer want to use by clicking it once and selecting Remove . If the language is correct but the layout isn't (for example, if you're using the US English keyboard in the DVORAK layout rather the QWERTY), select the language, click Options , choose Add a keyboard , and then choose the desired layout to add it.

steps.title: Switch the keyboard language using the Input menu icon.
steps.content: Switch the keyboard language using the Input menu icon. If your keyboard is typing characters from the wrong language when you type, it's usually because the wrong language is selected as the input language. To switch to a different language quickly, click the current language's icon in the menu bar at the top of the screen and select the language you want to type in. Depending on your version of macOS, this icon may look like a country flag, or it might be just a two-letter language code (e.g., US for US English). If you don't see this icon, you'll have to activate it, which you'll learn to do in a moment.

steps.title: Open your Mac's System Settings.
steps.content: Open your Mac's System Settings . You can get there by clicking the Apple icon at the top-left corner and selecting System Settings from the menu. If you’re using an old version of macOS, this option may be called System Preferences instead.

steps.title: Click the Keyboard icon.
steps.content: Click the Keyboard icon. Scroll down in the sidebar on the left side of the System Settings window to find it. This opens your keyboard settings. In older versions of macOS, you’ll find it in the main System Preferences window.

steps.title: Click Edit… next to “Input Sources”.
steps.content: Click Edit… next to “Input Sources”. You’ll find this setting under the Text Input header about halfway down the screen. [2] X Research source If you’re using an older version of macOS, click the Input Sources tab at the top of the window instead.

steps.title: Toggle on "Show Input menu in menu bar".
steps.content: Toggle on "Show Input menu in menu bar". You’ll see this option at the top of the menu. Click the toggle switch to turn it on (the toggle will move right and turn blue when it’s in the ON position). In older versions of macOS, this box is at the bottom of the window. When this setting is turned on, the Input menu will display in the menu bar. You can now click the icon to switch keyboard languages at any time.

steps.title: Remove any languages you don't want to use (optional).
steps.content: Remove any languages you don't want to use (optional). If you want to completely remove a keyboard language from your Mac, you can do so by clicking that language and then clicking the minus sign below the language list.

steps.title: Add another language (optional).
steps.content: Add another language (optional). If your preferred keyboard language does not appear on the list, you can add it by clicking the + below the list, selecting the language, choosing a keyboard layout, and then clicking Add .

steps.title: Click Done.
steps.content: Click Done . When you’re finished making any adjustments to the Input Sources settings, click Done at the bottom of the window. This will take you back to the main Settings window.

steps.title: Open the Device Manager.
steps.content: Open the Device Manager. This program allows you to reset hardware on your computer. A faulty driver can be responsible for all sorts of keyboard problems on Windows PCs, including erratic behavior and unresponsiveness. This method will help you delete the current driver and replace it with a clean version. To open Device Manager: If your keyboard is working, click the Start menu, type device manager into the search bar, and then click Device Manager in the search results. If you can't type, click the Start menu, scroll down the programs list, expand the Windows System folder, select Control Panel , and then click Device Manager .

steps.title: Scroll down and expand Keyboard.
steps.content: Scroll down and expand Keyboard . Click the arrow icon to the left of the Keyboard heading. A drop-down list of your currently connected keyboards will appear.

steps.title: Select the keyboard that you want to reset.
steps.content: Select the keyboard that you want to reset. Click on a keyboard's name to select it. The names of the keyboard might be generic, such as "Standard PS/2 Keyboard" or "HID Keyboard Device." If you have a laptop and have connected a secondary keyboard (connected via USB or through a USB-based wireless receiver), the "Standard" keyboard is the one built into the laptop, and the HID keyboard is the secondary one. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click the "Uninstall" icon.
steps.content: Click the "Uninstall" icon. It's the red X at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click Uninstall to confirm.
steps.content: Click Uninstall to confirm. Doing so removes the keyboard from the Device Manager.

steps.title: Click the "Scan for hardware changes" icon.
steps.content: Click the "Scan for hardware changes" icon. It's the computer monitor icon in the upper-right side of the Device Manager window. Clicking this will scan your PC for connected hardware that doesn't have a driver (such as your keyboard) and reinstall the driver automatically. At this point, try using your keyboard again. If it works, great! If not, you may need to install a specific driver. You can also continue with this method to try updating the driver. If your external keyboard is not detected, unplug it (or power it off completely if it's connected via Bluetooth). When you plug it back in or turn it back on, Windows should install the drivers automatically.

steps.title: Select the keyboard again.
steps.content: Select the keyboard again. The keyboard's name will appear in the Keyboards section. Depending on the driver used to reinstall it, it may have a different name than it did before.

steps.title: Click the "Update drivers" button.
steps.content: Click the "Update drivers" button. This option is at the top of the window, and looks like a black box with a green arrow facing upward.

steps.title: Click Search automatically for updated driver software.
steps.content: Click Search automatically for updated driver software . It's the top option in the pop-up window. This will prompt Windows to begin searching for the most recent software updates for your keyboard.

steps.title: Allow the newest drivers to install.
steps.content: Allow the newest drivers to install. If there are any drivers available for your keyboard they will install automatically. If there aren't any new drivers, click Search for updated drivers on Windows Update . If an update is available, click Install now to download it—Windows Update is the best way to get the latest drivers for your PC. You may be prompted to restart your PC after updating the drivers.

steps.title: Open your Mac's System Settings.
steps.content: Open your Mac's System Settings . You can find it by clicking the Apple menu at the upper-left corner of the screen and selecting System Settings on the menu. In older versions of macOS, this option is called System Preferences instead. Use this method if you've tweaked some keyboard settings, such as shortcuts and automatic corrects, but want to return to the defaults.

steps.title: Click Keyboard.
steps.content: Click Keyboard . This keyboard-shaped icon is in the menu bar on the left side of the System Settings window. In older versions of macOS, it’s in the main System Preferences window. Clicking it opens your Keyboard settings to a tab called Keyboard by default. If you're not on the Keyboard tab, click Keyboard near the top of the window to go there now.

steps.title: Click Keyboard Shortcuts….
steps.content: Click Keyboard Shortcuts… . You’ll see this button about halfway down the Keyboard settings menu.

steps.title: Go through the tabs and select Restore Defaults.
steps.content: Go through the tabs and select Restore Defaults . In the window that pops up, you’ll see a series of tabs in the menu pane on the left. These will display any keyboard shortcuts that are associated with each part of your system (e.g., your Display settings, specific apps, and so on). Click on each one and then click Restore Defaults on the bottom left side of the window. The last tab on the list, Modifier Keys , will display the actions that are associated with your keyboard’s special keys (such as Fn , Control , and Option ). If you’ve made any changes to these defaults, you can reset them here. In older versions of macOS, go to System Preferences > Keyboard > Keyboard tab > Modifier Keys to change your modifier key settings. When you’re finished, click Done to close the window.

steps.title: Click Text Replacements… and remove unwanted settings.
steps.content: Click Text Replacements… and remove unwanted settings. In the main Keyboard settings window, select Text Replacements… . It’s under the Text Input header. A window will open displaying any automatic text replacements you have in your settings (for example, replacing “omw” with “On my way!”). Select any you don’t want and click the - button. Click Done to close the window. In earlier versions of macOS, you can find this list of replacements in System Preferences > Keyboard > Text tab .

steps.title: Click the Accessibility icon in Settings.
steps.content: Click the Accessibility icon in Settings. When you’re done with your changes in the main Keyboard Settings menu, navigate to Accessibility in the left-hand menu of System Settings . It's the blue circle with a white outline of a person inside.

steps.title: Click Keyboard.
steps.content: Click Keyboard . You’ll find this under the Motor header.

steps.title: Toggle off any settings you don’t want.
steps.content: Toggle off any settings you don’t want. Check if any settings have been turned on that you’d rather not use, such as "Enable Sticky Keys", "Enable Slow Keys," or "Accessibility Keyboard". If any of these options are enabled, disabling them will restore your Mac's original method of keyboard input. These options are accessibility features designed to make typing easier for people with limited mobility. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Restart your Mac
steps.content: Restart your Mac . Most of your changes should go into effect right away, but if they don’t, try restarting your Mac. Open the Apple menu , click Restart... , and click Restart when prompted. Your Mac's keyboard should be back to normal once your Mac finishes restarting.

steps.title: Turn off your Bluetooth keyboard.
steps.content: Turn off your Bluetooth keyboard. The location of the power button varies by keyboard, but you'll usually find it on the bottom or side of the keyboard. Use this method if you're having trouble keeping your Bluetooth keyboard paired to your PC.

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings.
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . You'll find this gear icon in your Start menu, toward the bottom-left side.

steps.title: Click Devices.
steps.content: Click Devices . It's the icon of a keyboard and smartphone.

steps.title: Click the Bluetooth and other devices tab.
steps.content: Click the Bluetooth and other devices tab. It's on the left side of the window. If Bluetooth is disabled, click the "Bluetooth" switch at the top to turn it on.

steps.title: Click your keyboard in the device list.
steps.content: Click your keyboard in the device list. It'll be under "Mouse, keyboard, & pen." A "Remove device" button will expand.

steps.title: Click the Remove device button.
steps.content: Click the Remove device button. A confirmation window will appear.

steps.title: Click Yes to confirm.
steps.content: Click Yes to confirm. This unpairs the keyboard from your computer. If Bluetooth is disabled, you'll need to reenable it now.

steps.title: Turn your keyboard on and click + Add Bluetooth or other device.
steps.content: Turn your keyboard on and click + Add Bluetooth or other device . It's at the top of the right panel.

steps.title: Click Bluetooth.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth . It's the first option. Your PC will now scan for Bluetooth devices .

steps.title: Click your keyboard when it appears in the list.
steps.content: Click your keyboard when it appears in the list. Depending on your keyboard, additional instructions may appear on the screen. Follow them, if so.

steps.title: Click Done.
steps.content: Click Done . You've now re-paired your Bluetooth keyboard to your PC.

steps.title: Turn off your keyboard.
steps.content: Turn off your keyboard. Press and hold the Power button on the back of the keyboard (for newer models) or on the right side (for older models) for at least three seconds to turn it off. [5] X Research source Use this method if you're having trouble keeping your Bluetooth keyboard paired to your Mac. You may need a Lightning cable to pair your keyboard back to your Mac. Make sure you have one available.

steps.title: Open your Mac's Apple menu .
steps.content: Open your Mac's Apple menu . Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click System Settings.
steps.content: Click System Settings . It's near the top of the drop-down menu. In older versions of macOS, this is called System Preferences .

steps.title: Click Bluetooth.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth . It's the icon that looks like a sideways bowtie or ribbon. It’s located near the top of the left-hand menu in System Settings . If Bluetooth isn't on, toggle on the switch next to Bluetooth at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click the i next to your keyboard in the list.
steps.content: Click the i next to your keyboard in the list. A new popup window will open.

steps.title: Click Forget This Device….
steps.content: Click Forget This Device… . In the warning message that pops up, click Forget again to confirm.

steps.title: Press and hold your keyboard's Power button to turn it back on.
steps.content: Press and hold your keyboard's Power button to turn it back on. When the keyboard comes back on, it will reappear in your list of Bluetooth devices. Click on it to reconnect if it doesn’t connect automatically. If your keyboard doesn't reappear in the list of Bluetooth devices, connect it to your Mac using a Lightning cable. Once connected, it should activate Bluetooth and automatically pair your keyboard. [6] X Research source
